user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of set_self_name:
```c
static void
set_self_name (int argc, char *const *argv)
{
  if ((argc >= 1) && (NULL != argv[0]))
  {
    const char *last_dir_sep;
    last_dir_sep = strrchr (argv[0], '/');
#ifdef _WIN32
    if (1)
    {
      const char *last_w32_dir_sep;
      last_w32_dir_sep = strrchr (argv[0], '\\');
      if ((NULL == last_dir_sep) ||
          ((NULL != last_w32_dir_sep) && (last_w32_dir_sep > last_dir_sep)))
        last_dir_sep = last_w32_dir_sep;
    }
#endif /* _WIN32 */
    if (NULL != last_dir_sep)
    {
      size_t name_len;
      name_len = strlen (last_dir_sep + 1);
      if ((0 != name_len) && ((sizeof(self_name) / sizeof(char)) > name_len))
      {
        strcpy (self_name, last_dir_sep + 1);
        return;
      }
    }
  }
  /* Set default name */
  strcpy (self_name, "perf_replies");
  return;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
/* Set default name */
  strcpy (self_name, "perf_replies");
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The default strcpy is reachable (so Rule 2.1 is not violated). For example, calling set_self_name(0, NULL) makes the initial (argc >= 1) test false and execution falls through to the default: strcpy(self_name, "perf_replies"). It is also reached if argv[0] contains no directory separator (so last_dir_sep == NULL) or if the extracted name is empty or too large to fit in self_name.
